Python Nodes

Camera Point Handler

Camera Point Handler Node.

This ROS2 node receives detected persons from a camera topic, transforms their positions into the odometry coordinate frame, and visualizes them as RViz markers.

Features: - Deterministic color assignment per person ID - First and last trajectory points visualized as spheres - Movement direction visualized as an arrow

class marker_visualization.marker_visualization.CameraPointHandler(*args: Any, **kwargs: Any)[source]

ROS2 node for processing and visualizing camera-based person detections.

The node: - subscribes to a Persons topic published by a camera pipeline - transforms points from the camera frame to the odometry frame - publishes RViz markers for visualization

get_color_for_person(person_id)[source]

Generate a deterministic RGB color for a person.

The color is derived from the person ID so that the same person is always visualized with the same color.

Parameters:

person_id (int) – Unique identifier of the person

Returns:

RGB color values in range [0.0, 1.0]

Return type:

tuple[float, float, float]

persons_callback(msg)[source]

Callback for received person detection messages.

For each person: - the first and last trajectory points are visualized as spheres - an arrow marker is published to indicate movement direction

Parameters:

msg (Persons) – Message containing detected persons

publish_arrow(first, last, marker_id, person_id)[source]

Create and publish an arrow marker between two points.

The arrow represents the movement direction of a person.

Parameters:

  • first (Point) – Start point in the camera frame

  • last (Point) – End point in the camera frame

  • marker_id (int) – Marker identifier

  • person_id (int) – Person ID used for color assignment

publish_person_point(p, marker_id, person_id)[source]

Prepare and publish a sphere marker for a person point.

The point is wrapped in a PointStamped, transformed into the target frame, and then published as a sphere marker.

Parameters:

  • p (Point) – Point in the camera coordinate frame

  • marker_id (int) – Unique marker identifier

  • person_id (int) – Person ID used for color assignment

marker_visualization.marker_visualization.main(args=None)[source]

Entry point for the CameraPointHandler node.

Initializes rclpy, spins the node, and ensures a clean shutdown on exit.

Odometry Logger

Odometry Logger Node.

This ROS2 node subscribes to odometry information and builds a continuous nav_msgs/Path message from the received poses.

The generated path can be visualized in RViz to show the trajectory of the robot over time.

class odom_logger.odom_logger.OdomLogger[source]

ROS2 node for logging odometry data and publishing a path.

The node: - subscribes to an odometry topic - extracts the robot pose from each message - appends the pose to a nav_msgs/Path - publishes the accumulated path for visualization

odom_callback(msg)[source]

Callback for received odometry messages.

Extracts the robot pose from the odometry message, converts it into a PoseStamped, appends it to the internal path, and publishes the updated path.

Parameters:

msg (Odometry) – Odometry message containing the robot pose

odom_logger.odom_logger.main(args=None)[source]

Entry point for the OdomLogger node.

Initializes rclpy, spins the node, and performs a clean shutdown when the node stops.

Camera Publisher

class camera_publisher.camera_pub.CameraPublisher[source]

ROS 2 node for publishing camera-based person detections from shared memory.

This node reads prediction results written by an external process into shared memory and publishes them as ROS messages of type robot_msgs.msg.Persons.

Each detected person is identified by a unique ID and represented by a sequence of 3D points in the camera coordinate frame.

Optionally, the node can also publish RGB camera images from shared memory as sensor_msgs.msg.Image.

Shared memory layout for person predictions:

int32   num_targets
uint64  timestamp_ns
for each target:
    int32   person_id
    int32   num_points
    float32 x, y, z  (per point)
connect_shm_image()[source]

Connect to the shared memory segment containing the camera image.

The shared memory buffer is interpreted as a NumPy array with a fixed shape and data type.

connect_shm_persons()[source]

Connect to the shared memory segment containing person predictions.

If the shared memory segment does not exist yet, the connection attempt fails silently and will be retried during the next publish cycle.

publish_all()[source]

Periodic timer callback.

Publishes person detections and, optionally, the camera image.

publish_image()[source]

Publish the camera image from shared memory as a ROS image message.

The image is copied from shared memory, converted using cv_bridge, and published with the current ROS time.

publish_persons()[source]

Publish detected persons as a robot_msgs.msg.Persons message.

The message timestamp is derived from the shared memory timestamp to preserve temporal consistency with the source data.

read_predictions()[source]

Read person prediction data from shared memory.

The shared memory buffer is parsed according to the predefined binary layout. The method extracts the timestamp, person IDs, and associated 3D point sequences.

Returns:

  • int or None: Timestamp in nanoseconds, or None if no shared memory data is available.

  • list: A list of tuples (person_id, points), where points is a list of (x, y, z) tuples.

Return type:

tuple

camera_publisher.camera_pub.main(args=None)[source]

Entry point for the CameraPublisher node.

Initializes rclpy, spins the node, and ensures a clean shutdown on exit.
